Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Shoup Fractionation and Cryogenic Gas Plant resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to the process.  Other recommendations for possible changes to improve safety come from periodic accident prevention program audits, incident investigations, or employee suggestions and recommendations.  The following changes are planned for implementation at the Shoup Fractionation and Cryogenic Gas Plant.

* No changes are planned.

Hand-held fire extinguishers
* Personnel trained in emergency response and procedures.
* Personnel protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus, etc.)

Five Year Accident History

Records are kept for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  The following is a brief summary of accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:

This facility has had no accidental releases in the last five years which meets the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10.

Emergency Procedures Information

The Shoup Fractionation and Cryogenic Gas Plant maintains a written emergency procedure, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The procedures are for the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address notification of local emergency response agencies if a release occurs.  Employees receive training in emergency procedures.  The emergency procedure is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the terminal facilities.   

The overall emergency procedure program for the Shoup Plant is coordinated with the Nueces County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials and industry representatives. The Shoup Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Shoup Plant conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations, and the Shoup Plant provides periodic refresher training to local emergency responde

provided through the use of written operating procedures, employee training in written procedures, including normal operation and emergency release procedures, and in the design of safety and release prevention equipment installed at the terminal site.  In addition, a written safety program designed to comply with all applicable OSHA safety performance regulations is strictly enforced at all Enterprise facilities, including the Shoup Fractionation and Cryogenic Gas Plant facility.  As part of the Enterprise safety program, the facility utilizes procedures that are included in the Enterprise program, but may not specifically be required at non-PSM and/or RMP Program 1 facilities (e.g. Safe work practice training; safe work permitting and hot work permitting).

Universal Prevention Activities

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all RMP covered processes at Shoup Fractionation and Cryogenic Gas Plant.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Specialized Safety Features

The Shoup Fractionation and Cryogenic Gas Plant has safety features on many units to help contain/control a release, to quickly detect a release and reduce the consequence of a release.  The following types of safety features are used in the covered processes:

Release Detection

* Hydrocarbon (hazardous gas) detectors and alarms
* Fire detectors inside plant compressor buildings.

Release Containment and Control

* Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases.
* Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automated).
* Automatic shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high temperature).
* Curbs or dikes to contain liquid releases.
* Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system)
* Atmospheric relief devices.

Release Mitigation

inlet gas. The plant also receives additional recovered natural gas liquids from other gas processing plants in South Texas via several inlet hydrocarbon liquid pipelines. The mixed hydrocarbon liquid streams produced at or delivered to the Shoup facility are fractionated into individual, purified ethane, propane, butane-plus natural gas liquid streams. Finished products are residual natural gas from the cryogenic plant and fractionated hydrocarbon liquids which are removed from the plant by pipeline systems and, in the case of the propane, butane-plus liquids, also by tractor trailer trucks.

The Shoup Fractionation and Cryogenic Gas Plant process is regulated by Federal OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.  We have entered the facility as an RMP Program Level 1 facility.

Toxics

There are no toxic materials contained on site above the threshold limits.

Flammables

The Shoup Fractionation and Cryogenic Gas Plant was evaluated to determine if any regulated flammable substances exceeded the threshold quantity.  Enterprise identified the regulated substances and quantities to be kept on site based on the process design of the proposed process vessels. Listed flammable substances which are present above the threshold quantities at the Shoup Fractionation and Cryogenic Gas Plant are natural gas (methane), ethane, propane, iso-butane, normal butane, iso-pentane and pentane.

Offsite Consequence Analysis Results

The offsite consequence analysis will not be reflected in the executive summary but rather is reflected in the data components.  There are flammable substances on site and no toxic substances above the threshold quantity.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Shoup Fractionation and Cryogenic Gas Plant
Enterprise Products Operating LLC
Executive Summary Risk Management Plan
EPA Identifier: 1000 0008 9281

Accidental Release Prevention and Response

At Enterprise, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation
* An overview of our accidental release prevention programs
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's RMP rule
* An overview of our emergency response program
* An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Shoup Fractionation and Cryogenic Gas Plant located in Nueces County, Texas is owned by Enterprise Gas Processing L.L.C. and is operated by Enterprise. The Shoup Plant is a combined processing complex comprised of a cryogenic natural gas liquid recovery plant and natural gas liquids fractionation equipment. The natural gas liquid recovery plant is designed to utilize the cryogenic turbo expander process to recover natural gas liquids from the inlet gas, and is assembled primarily from prefabricated, skid-mounted process components. Produced natural gas is delivered to the facility from a gas gathering system and inlet gas pipeline.
